element_texts.text: Completed

Bangor July 21st 1839
Dearest Mother       also brother
Charles was down here Friday and gave me a letter from you, but I hardly had a chance to speak to him.  I saw him coming in, in the morning, as I was out hoeing praties. but before I had eaten my breakfast, and got down town, he was gone; So I dont know whether he got some money of Morren?, or sold his wool, or got me a ? on Me!  I have been tryingunderlined to prepare a composition, also writing to Ann about some book etc. to day; rather worldly employment to be sure, but I am hurried, there is great scrabble, in school now about review and preparation for examinations?  There is one thing which I want a little advice about.  I expect that James ? Walker would be very glad of an invite to go up to Milo with me and make hay a spell.  Now the thing is would it do?  considering etc.  He would have the tactunderlined to see whether he wanted I spose, but I think he would like to come if he were urged a little.  I should not have written now except for this, as I wrote so lately  Somehow I thought Charles did not look quite so well, healthy, as usual, when he was down here.  Is his health good now? I did not have a chance to see or speak to him, hardly at all, I don't know whether he noticed me in morning, or not, I was up to the farm with Mr. W. and James, hoeing potatoes; but he took the Centre St. so I could not speak to him.  I have not hardly concluded yet, whether to run home and go to haying before school is finished or stay and take the consequences at the Examination. I have been trying to hammer out a composition for a about a week.  As I had nothing to write about and nothing to write about I could not make out much.  I have been trying to espatch up something, by taking a peice out one book and a slice out of another, a line here and a sentence there, twisting it every way, but I fear they will convict me of Plagiarism  I could not do any better no harm though as I can see
Completed

Mr. C.W. Rich
                                                                                                             Milo

Our garden does look beautifully now. I can tell you The beans and the Cucumbers are blooming out, the beetroots are bigger than my thumb considerable also carrots 1/2 inch thick. We have had three messes of peas already. some of the cabbages have begun to head.
I have tore my drab pants in the knee rather bad to day Friday. I wish I had waited about one week first!
There has been a meeting of the S.S.C. to day to arrange about the Examiners Share I have not yet the programe in order of exercises, but the Eve. is to be Thurs. instead of Friday as Mr. Worcester is agoing to Boston in the Steamboat ? I am awful skeert about the Examin. every body is  the world will be there, most. Mr. Pomroy was here to tea today and said he should be there.
I expect that James would like very well to go somewhere and make hay a spell as he has nothing to do hardly now and I guess he would come home with me if he were invited but I guess it is not best to urge him.

                                                                                                        I.S. Metcalf

[left-hand side] Isaac Bangor

                        July 21, 1839
Completed

Bangor September 3rd 1839

Dear Mother
I am here again at my old stand, although not yet hardly settld in business I suppose that Joseph has got home by this time, and can inform you of all our doings.  I thought it would be best to have the wool here and I might be able to sell it sometime; it is now safely stored away up garret.  Hardy any one wanted to buy wool, it had fallen at Boston and New York, and they said they have lost money by what they had bought, 33 and a third seemed the common price, but at Campbell and Mils, I was offered 37 half.  I thought Charles would not be willing to have it sold at that price and that it had better stay here.
On going to school this morning, the scholars all appeared glad to see me again, more afraid they had lost me so, but Mr. Worcester said never a word till the Latin Class were called, he heard all before me, and then addressed me thus; "Isaac, you left school before the close of the term, and according to the regulations of the Committee, I have no authority to admit to the school, without a certificate from Mr. Abbot, C.L.L.B."
At recess I left the school and went over to Mr. Abbots office.  After inquiring into the particulars of the case, he very readily gave me a certificate of readmission.
[bottom of page upside down] Perhaps James would be glad of the chance to take a letter or bundle
[left-hand side] I suppose I could send anything to Boston next week by James.  He will probably go next week Wed.  Possibly not till the next bout a week.  If you could send me a letter here I could send it by him-easily.
Completed

Mr. Asa Walker is now gone to Wilton, with his ? started yesterday morning, will be back Friday or Saturday, Mrs. Walker is I should think in much better health than when I left here, and does the work while Mr. W and his sister are gone.  James is going to Mass., after  'Lection, he says Mr. Walker has got two new young pigs which he intends to keep through the winter.    The other pigs are great hogs.  I find that I am rather behind the rest in some things, they have a week start of me.  There is a class beginning Comstocks Philosophy, and I must begin with them although I lack time for it.  There are 11 new scholars this term besides of who left at the beginning of summer, returned.
There is a class, many of the older boys and those who have studied algebra going to go through the new Leonards Arithmetick, lately published, to refresh their memories etc.
It is very oppressively warm to lay, especially in a schoolhouse;  James says I shall soon lose the flesh I have gained, studying, this weather.  It comes very hard to wear a thick warm coat all day, or a stick either.
I left behind as you will perceive my umbrella, shoes, inkbottle, they can be sent with the pantaloons.  I don't know but it would be best if I had that white jacket.  I rather think that that old wooden frock coat, which I wore some, when I first went home, (hanging upstairs) might be fixed by merely cutting off a few inches, of the bottom, putting on buttons etc, so that I could wear it to school considerable this fall.  At least digging potatoes etc.
It would save my other, (of which there is need/, and also, my p.pants much more than a short jacket.
Completed

Wed. 4th
School does not keep this afternoon.  I wish it had a Scientific Class Book; there is a class commencing it, it is just what I very much need to study, I should think.  I have a great notion of giving Algebra and paying more attention to History, Philosophy -.  I cannot attend to all Latin, Greek and every-thing at a  time.
James told me I had better get my coat made by Mr. Fox ? Market Sq,:that he did his work rather cheaper than other and he thought full as well; he always does their work.  He says he don't know of any woman, who makes coats here, soforth.  I have been into Mr. Fox's shop; his fixes one; for cutting and making a coat $5.00.  Trimmings, also extra $2,25 for frocks $2,00 for dress coats, cutting, alone, 75.  He said it would take 2 quarter yds for me a frock.  1 eighth for a dress coat.  There is but 2 yd of that of mine is there?  I am sure I don't know whether it is to be a frock coat, or not!  AT some of the other shops, at least the price for making $6, $5.020 is a s far as my cash extends, and I ought to have some boots immediately.
I want to know what it is best to do about the coat, selling the wool to, right away.  Mr. Fox could not make the coat until next week if it was there now, he ways.
There is to be a select school for young Ladies established here in a month or two, which I guess would have been a good situation for Anne, but the Teacher is already engaged, I believe A Miss.  from Brunswick.  It is expected that an assistant for Mr. Turner in the H.S will be wanted in the spring I believe.
Completed

Bangor September 15th 1839

Dear Mother
I received a bundle for you Thursday the 12th inst. containing a coat, pantaloons, vest and stockings;  I wanted those old shoes that I forgot also as I have nothing to wear now anywhere but the great thick boots.  The pants I shall wear a good deal, I guess, this fall, they are fixed up nicely.  The coat also will do me some good.  I guess but the sleeves and collar are so large that it looks awkwardly here; It would be just the thing to mean about all my work this fall and to school in cold, rainy weather, if I had any kind of a jacket; a thin one a baise ones are much worn here to work on school or anything a chick one.  I don't know but that camblet or old white one, only Joseph wants it and it is too very thick;  Something that would do to wear under it.  One frock coat wider another would not do so well you know.  You see how one want satisfied only makes another?  I believe that the price of wool is rising.  I guess that it will sell soon pretty well.  I had better sell it if you get, 50 per bbl. had not I.  The tailor says that I can have a frock from my cloth by  having a velvet collar, which would cost $1,25 and they are much worn so, on it would make a dress coat and a single breasted vest.  I concluded that the dress coat, vest, and $1,25 would do me more good than the frock coat.  However Frocks are much the most worn , now here, he says that there will have to be some more silk and and also some cord for binding.  Moreover that he would wait a piece for a part to pay, if it was not on hand to.  I guess that he's a real good sort of man.  Elen. T Fox W.M. Square.  he is to get the rest of silk etc.
Completed

I have left of studying Algebra as I found I could not get along with it fervently.  I find that the others have got the start of me somewhat since the 26th of July last.  Some of them studied some during the vacation I guess.  We shall commence the Greek Reader tomorrow.  Mine has not yet arrived but I guess borrow one from somebody.  I do not study History as yet but think I shall when the class gets to English History, as I feel a great lacking in that reflect.
I guess that the Scientific class Book that they have here is not the one Amos is acquainted with, this is an advanced work, goes entirely further than Cornstocks, it takes Natural Philosophy in it  widest sense - Mon 16th I found at the steamboat office this morn a bundle for me, containing two school books for me, a signing sentences for Ann, and 3 letters, 2 of them from Mr. Bush.  I will send Josephs and Mothers' as soon as I can with this etc.  The freight was $5,25.  The book are just the thing, I wanted.  I want to know what Ann gave for them.  The other scholars have to give $1,12half for the reader here!  I expect we shall have to fly round to keep along when we study in the Reader too.  They say it is awful hard.
5'O'clock Coming home from school tonight, I perceived Mr. Ellis, wandering about in search of the habitation of me F. Addams. 1 Kenneth place and directed him to it, and I meant to get him carry up my bundle of letters etc.
I am losing my required flesh and strength fast already line unclear because of crease
I certainly can't enjoy myself as well as at work.  I shall study till next spring if health permits and then you see.  You must all write.  Ann must write to me, and all of you.  I feel almost like an exile!!  Don't think I am discouraged on however or dissatisfied with my situation for it is not so intolerant - but
Bangor Isaac
Sept. 15 '39
Completed

Bangor Cot 2d 1839  Sunday noon

Dear Mother
I got here as Eliab has told you when you read this.  I am here at Ms. Walkers:  Eliab I feel has a cold side home.  He ought to have had some mittens.  Send me my gown and my shirt that Isaac had at Barn for with the potatoes if possible.  I did go to meeting this forenoon but am going this afternoon.  They say that probably (on account of headwind etc.) the steamboat will not arrive here tonight & therefore I will not repost till about noon tomorrow.  I have eat dinner here, Mr Walker's folks have got 1 new wrinkle - they take a great long baked potato in 1 hand & a knife in other & dunk it into a bowl of milk & eat it with a spoon like bread & milk.
Good bye, Joseph with a poor pen.
1 o'clock, The steamer has not yet arrived.  It may come up in the night as there is a good moon.  If it arrives in the morning it will start to depart at a new moon.  The usual time of the books arrives is 9 o' clock.  R.M of starting out M. - but it is very irregular now a days - sometimes when foggy I has not started until 8 in the morning.  I am at the present time up in Isaac chamber which is very respectable & warmed by a drum in the stove funnel!! with Isaac's steel pen in my hand, Isaac sitting by my side reading & James S Walker putting on his coat to go to a evening meeting.  These drab trousers are rather cold and thin, I fear it will be cool on board the boat with a deck passage.  I attended the Pomroy meeting cet apres dinée Text "The path of the just is a shining light that shineth more & more unto the perfect day." Proverbs 4:8
Monday, half past 9 at M The Bangor has not arrived yet but is expected every moment.  The Bangor banks have all stopped spare payments & the bills of the Bangor Bank or considered doubtful good - I have exchanged the $85.00 Bangor bank bill ((from Col. see)) for two of the Frankfort bank current about here but uncurrent in Boston - Bank of Newburyport of Portland a $2 - & a $1- good in Boston or anywhere.  (I changed it at E.J Dowers)

How is my jacket to be sent and render me by afternoon?  Can you cut it without me to fit it by?
Completed

I can let Isaac have the $2.00 of the Frankfurt bank bills & perhaps more but the others $7.00 is current in Boston.  Perhaps it is for the best that the steamer does not arrive as the sea will have some time to calk after the gale of Sat & Sunday, before I start.  Isaac is in school -  half past 10 A.M.  Not come has the steamer P.M  The steamboat has not arrived yet.  I have been "looking" all day & I am most sick if not quit of the Andre.  I sincerely with I had worn the dark colored pants as these are thin & have no lining.  I wish I was at home.  I have given Isaac $2.62 of the $10.50 which I seen.  He has paid Mr Fox the $1.00 due for making the coat, I carried his coat down  let "  " to have it enlarged about -the waist.  All or about day keep this more I was on the steamboat wharf - calculate to be tomorrow morning.  I looked at the book store this afternoon  and read Fritz Hazell one of the Temperance Tales. Tuesday morn 6A.M The steamboat has not come what is to be done.   
12 A.M The steamer arrived about half hour ago.  Starts on about 1/2 hour.  I attended the Launching of a schooner this forenoon.
Good bye, from your affectionate son Joseph.  Good bye all.
Tuesday eve
The boat steam boat, (Joseph and all) started a little after one o clock today, it did not arrive till about 11 or aver on account of the violent North on N.E wind.  Sunday Monday etc the Portland did not stand from Boston till - Joseph has staid here at Mr. Walkers, took 6-7 meals here.
I don't know but it was rather bad for him to stay here so long but it could not be helped, and Mr. W. told him to stay make himself perfectly easy.
Joseph got rather tired of waiting for the boat:- doing nothing or loafing as the term here is:  he helped me cut wood some.  head home etc.etc.
Joseph carries up a letter to put in the Boston P.O from I.L Walker and just before the boat started, A Mr. Little of this city with whom James is some acquainted was enquiring for some one to send a letter.
Completed

by, and James told him of Joseph and said he was trusty etc. The letter contained $75. dollars in bills and was for a Mr. Rodgers of  Tremont St. Boston. Mr. Little wanted he should give it to Mr. R. and get a receipt for it and send back. I should think if was considerable confidence to put in an entire stranger - one whom he had never before seen. As the Boat was starting a spark from the flue caught in the top of the front Foremast and was not seen till it had burst the shrouds, ropes- off and fell but it was extinguished without much damage. There was a very strong S.W.  wind when the boat started and it was was much as ever could get turned round and started fairly - no till after two trials.
I want very much to know how Elian got here Sun. He must have had a very cold ride against the wind all day. I thought of the poor fellow, much during the day - perhaps I suppose about as much, sitting by the fire and thinking of him as he did himself. I meant to have given him Joseph great thick Comforter but did not. I want the mittens again. Eliab most ought to have staid and looked at the (City) a spell. He did not hardly see a (Shop) or a (Meeting house) It was awful cold and windy and I had just come out of a new Store crossed out room, with very thin clothes and he and Joseph were cold moreover twas Sunday. there was hardly two people in the whole streets.
I have paid Mr. Fox for my coat, rest etc. and carried my coat to him, he is a going to let it out a little. I shall send the rest up. I dont know hardly what it is best to do about getting boots and shoes, I suppose these boots will last me all winter and they are just as good in the winter. I guess I had better have a pair of thickish shoes, that will come up pretty high on my ankles, to near round - to school in fair weather etc. they will have my boots and help them through the winter. It is a great pity I did not have them a month ago. I am getting along decently about clothes, after a fashion, except pants to near to meeting Do have my newer crossed out pantaloons set somewhere or other decent if possible
Completed

Isaac  & Joseph
Oct. 20  39
Bangor 

              Bangor                                                         Mr. C.W. Rich
               Oct. 23                                                         Milo

Wed. Mr. Fox has fix'd my coat, it is now big enough so that I can button it. It seems to me very short waisted, but I suppose it is the Fashion! The rest is cut out and I shall send it up you will see that there are very few peices left. I shall need this winter much more than that fine vest, a common, coarsinch, thick, nam double breasted vest made out of most any thing. Mayo said that he did not know but Charles would be down some time this week. perhaps, I had better send this. What had I better do about getting shoes here? blotted out A $1,87 1/2 none I shall have to have an Cicero, I suppose in 4 or 5 weeks, or more. We got through the Virgil Aeneid Sat. then review etc.
Completed

Wednes. afternoon

Dear Mother
I got here in good time about three o clock found Mrs. W without any girl, a new one came Monday Morn; ; James W. is coming here in a week or two, to help tear down the house, and a carpenter is coming too, by and by!  The girl is quite young (note the good old one who cannot come yet) and without exactly asking I have found out that Mrs. W would not want any addition to the family but I think Lucy had better come and board at Mr. Cutlers, they would probably board here a little cheaper if she did her own washing and perhaps might pay part in produce at his store and C. take the money instead.  She would learn as much there about behavior company as here, and with regarding to introducing her time out of school, she must learn to have decision of character and independence enough to do what is right and proper without being led by others; a most useful lesson and one that can be gained best by experience.  I should have gone on up to Mr. Cutler's this afternoon if it had just raised, but there is not doubt but they will take her and she must get ready as soon as she can.  I shall send word as soon as I have been there and she had better come as soon as possible afterward, so as to be here as near the beginning of the term as she can.  Well, what kind of a school will she go to?  Why, the committee who came in yesterday, called it a new select school for girls, in telling the scholars (and teacher too I suppose) how much they expected of them.  It consists of 44 girls, from 10 to 15 mostly, no boys, so you see it is just the school for Lucy and if she comes with a determination to study she can improve much and be a help to me.  I should rather she would go to Mr. Pomroy' meeting and perhaps I can arrange it so as to have her in our S.S in that case she would attending meeting here in the forenoon, though that meeting is as good as this.

 I want my thick shoes to work in the garden with.
[top upside down] You must write often. Joseph and Eliab must write all how they get along with the work this warm weather.
Completed

Bangor  Wed. 22nd 1840P.M

Dear Mother
You know how Ann all last term kept thinking as how she had a bad school to manage, and did not get along well; the committee were not satisfied, did not have a good examination and all that.  I said that she did nicely.  How did it turn out?  This term she has got, I suppose the very best school, taught by a female in the city!!  A New Select School!!! consisting of girls only; just about the right number; just about the right age; and moreover, just the very place for Lucy!!!!!  The next thing is, I suppose, for Lucy to get here as soon as possible.  It seems as if you would need her at home this Summer, but I think it is altogether too good a chance to be lost, or found every day either, especially if she can get boarded at Mrs Cutlers for 7/6 per week.  Can't you get little Olive again this Summer?  It is a pity that Charles cannot improve this nice early spring, so as to get his crops in good season, and for once in the May, get fairly beforehand.  He ought to have had some of his wheat sown before this rain today: but I suppose he has not.  I fear he will conclude that his 6 days time and fuss spent for 10, dollars worth of hayseed, that he wanted to sow himself, was ......, not quite wasted, - but this applied.  It is so dark that I can write no longer.
I have sold the smallest box of butter for 14 cts per pound, 12 quarter pound $1,71 I have enquired somewhat, but do not think I shall be able to sell the seeds.  It is too late, every body has got a full stock, more than they can sell; it is possible that I could sell them for money I would take pay out of the store, not otherwise.
I was pretty lucky in selling the butter at 14 even I think; they were selling good butter out of the stores at 12 and 13, but one morn Almer Taylor who appeased to be a connoisseur, bring a little for his own family, took it home to use, but did not want the large box. 2 pounds was enough.  Perhaps I can sell some of the seed, as may as he want to sow, off to Mr. Walker, he has got all his seeds & garden to buy.
Completed

There is a class beginning French this term, or going to, I wish I could study with them, but I don't hardly know whether I should have time.  Besides I guess that should have to buy new books some, they begin upon a translation, which Ann has not got, you see I wish Joseph could be here this term, I do wish I could be at home this summer if it was not for studying most, I would be much more pleasant.  It's much harder work to study than to labor!!! To me at least (specially in the Summer) I sometime think how much better it would be if I could be to work at home, out of school where it is really needful; than to be here fusty fustin on little but garden, wheeling hour after hour from one end to the other, etc. Labor which might do more good somewhere else.
We are getting to work in our garden considerably, all ready to be done.  By the way if Charles is down again soon, I meant to send up some little lilac bushes if they would be taken care of, I could get some, lots of little schuleh flow round garden stairs.  
I want a Palm leaf hat, right away.  How shall I get it?
My cloth one is so warm; it does very well to wear to school this 2 months but ? work when it is as warm as today, for instance, and a thick cap is rather ?  I don't to give 2/6 for one again.  What has become of my old one.  I have been to Mr Cutlers today after school, found Mr. Hatch there visiting Naomi, I suppose, married says she will take Lucy cheaper than she would a stranger and for what we think right, I told her that I pay 150 including washing and that you would be glad to have her do her own if it would come cheaper.  Lucy must try to get her things in as good order as she can, so that what sewing she has to do will be plain and easy.
She will need to study considerable out of school because I shall need her help in school some I have 45 girls, many of them the best scholars selected from other schools and all the girls in Mr. Valentines: there will be much expected of me and justly.  Isaac rather implies, that I have the best school, because they consider me

  The butter is still in Parsons and Jaskery store unsold.  I miss in there Day 24th he said that butter be rising soon, and he could sell it that it had better.
Completed

so good a teacher but I know it not so, but because it happened to be convenient to make such an arrangement; I shall try to convince them that I am a good teacher this term, I certainly have a fair chance.  The sooner Lucy gets here the better her summer gowns will be suitable to put on soon, some wear pink dresses now.  She will need that she figured one of mine first.  Abby Hill one of my scholars.
I am waiting for you to write part of a letter before I write to A.

Care of Mr Charles . W Rich
Milo


Ann & Isaac, 1840 Bangor
[bottom of page upside down] I think Isaac had better study French they use Surault's Grammar. I have been trying to make him carry that frock coat to the tailor's but he has not, yet, I think it will make quite a garment.
Completed

Bangor Feb. 3rd 1840

Dear Mother
Charles was down here Sat. Feb. 1, but I did not see him at all!  Which was altogether too bad.  You see Ellen Lee called the eve before and said he was coming - he was not here till after school time and it was Sat and school kept by reason of Compositions till about dinner time.  So after dinner, I went downtown to look for him, hunted all over town and found him not!  Came home, and he had been here, staid on a few minutes and started for Milo!  I suppose that I went one way to look for him and he came up to Mr. W.s another and so we escaped one another.  I was a good deal disappointed.  You can't hardly think how much good it does one, when away to see anything from home.  Just to see the horses would be a pleasure.  You did not make out to write a very long letter, I believe and Eliab did not write any at all, what is the reason?  
You said you was going to send Josephs' last letter, but it did not come.  Also "Josephs letter to me, that we sent out, ought to be sent back, however?
Ann and I have recently written to Boston, a letter.  I received a letter from James Walker at Hancocks, a while ago and have lately answered it.  Sent last post Feb 1.
There is one thing, which I have forgotten every time, that  we have written home this term.  There was a little bundle of papers, tied or bound up with a paper, which I left at Milo, among the books be that Ann was to bring down.  She brought A not and I want it very much here.  It contained many different things, in south of things, skeletons of Compositions etc.!!
Completed
Completed

Feb 10th 8th 1840

Dear Mother
I write the following about a week since, but hurry bc. has prevented my finishing the thing, - it can hardly be called a letter.  I expect I took this old sheet about as much from laziness as anything.  Too lazy to write a good letter, on a good sheet, with a good pen.  So I took this to scribble on.
Is it not queer neater this winter, the snow is most all gone here, I guess Charles will not make out much, this winter, the weather, - be, have been such.  Had had better have kept school.  Mr. Walker is going to look up housekeeping, for a time and by, but not right away, perhaps in March what I do then?  Hope to get another place, or go home?  I don't hardly know whether I had better stay here and go to school this summer, (even if I can) or go to work, on the farm, or something.  I believe I have not changed my mind up about NOT going to college.  If I should go, I never should make anything. (line drawn)
Eliab must learn just as much as his situations permits, this does he have the mood to saw?  He don't have many calls to take care of when Charles is not there with the Horses - I wish I had him in my study, here some of these good long evenings, I would make him learn.  I know he must study evenings, much better than to go to singing schools!!
I get along some in my studies in Latin, Greek, but not very fast.  I find I have filled my sheet, such as it is, after a fashion, but I don't see as I have written much of any thing.  Do, take time and write me a good long letter, I want to know how things get along etc.
I.S Metcalf
Completed

Tues PM 3.o clock.  Samuel Fisher just called me out of school to give me a letter confined in this.  I going home tomorrow morning.  If I can just get time I will go down there this morning to Mr Wingate's.  I am dreadfully crowded for time just now, while the Writing school lasts every evening.  Leave to recite at 6. PM Then W.S. till 9 or 1/2 past all taken up in school.  If I can't be at school to have my lessons, as well as any.
As for the school the District posted at a partial meeting to employ a male teacher, although perhaps a majority want Ann to keep Mr. Edes has by direction, applied to me to know my terms & board myself.  I suppose they will give not much.  I hardly know what to do.  Whether to stand upon dignity & say 23 or 24, or try to get the school somehow.  Thought of seeing how cheap I could get boarded.  Ask the Parkers etc..  I should like to be here very well .  I could study some, Mr Tash would help me.  There is at school at the 4 corners, Foxcroft, I have spoke of.  Perhaps I can get it for Joseph one morning best, last winter.  I shall have more time when the writing school is over.  I ought to take some time to see the folks; 
Olive Furber has been up here, I guess I have not had time to call there or to Miss Dennett or any of the rest of my scholars!!  I have taken most to many studies, at least with visiting school it will not do for me to be backward on Com. or Declaim, you know got watch fixed & paid a quarter.  Grammar class is coming.  I should like that other pair of thin pants, if any of you come up.  I don't like my boarding place first rate, but time no excuse to leave.  What had I better do about the school.  Cost much to go west,
Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf

                 Foxcroft

Forward by Mr. Furber
Completed

I have just been out to Mr Parkers, he says thinks a majorly and best part of the district would like to keep but not a lot, even if meet up again & vote, as oppos'd, is so determined. He is anxious I should take it if possible instead of Woodman.  Board there.  7/6  I guess 
Write more and particularly if I don't. You have more time.
Isaac  Foxcroft  '43
Completed

Foxcroft Dec 7, 1843

Dear Mother
I can hardly realize now that you are two or three hundred miles from here, although I have been at home and staid a week.  Lonesome enough it seemed there, with no Mother and no Eliab.  The very idea of Home, seems to be made up principally of "Mother," and two or three others.
Our Examination at the Academy came off pretty well, rather better than usual, it is said.  We had a very good Exhibition the next day, or evening rather.  It was a long day and a damp & cloudy evening, but the meeting house was crowded full, and the audience sat with perfect patience and attention, till past one o clock, commencing at six.  Charles and Lucy did not come up, on account of the weather.  I was very sorry.  I wanted their opinion of the exact and comparative merit of my Oration!  
I spoke 20 min, house by accident very warm, & took cold through my carelessness, but have about got over it.  After settling up the Exhibition matters, I went home and stayed most a week.
Mr Fox died, as you have probably heard, ere this, on Wed. morn Nov. 22nd.  I did not hear it till I got home Sat night.  Charles watched with him the night he died.  I had a real lazy time, and got rested.  Lucy was pretty well.  Charles, I thought looked as if he wanted to see his Mum.  Perhaps as much as I did!!
I have commenced my school, and find it a case I have had near 70 scholars already, shall have some more after Thanksgiving (today) (They are almost all small ones, and such a restless, uneasy, witching set as I never saw before.  The control &
Completed

management of a hundred of the wildest or roughest young fellows, right out of the woods, or the street; in their teens, or olde would be nothing to it, as a kind of patience at least.
I shall probably have some larger scholars, next week.  I have 6 classes in reading, 5 in Arithmetic, 4 in Geography, 3 in Grammar, 1 in Philosophy, History, Algebra, 10 to 20 in a class generally.  I board at Mr Parkers'. I like the place pretty well, except that I do not have a room to myself which is rather disagreeable, as I have to keep to the hours of the other people instead of such as just me and go to bed in season!  10 o clock bed time here!!
I shall not have much chance to study this winter, I guess.
Dec 27th My letter will get out of date, into the new year before I send it.  Last Sat.  Mr Tash & P got a horse & sleigh & went down to Milo in the P.M to see the folks & spend the Sabbath.  Most unfortunately, we found Lucy sick a bed, all piled up with a lame ankle, unable to move!  You may imagine the fix!  However, we brushed round.  Almeda really undertook, fixed up her room & entertained us hospitably!  PM the end things leaped off not so bad as they might be although Lucy felt dreadfully about it at first.
We went up to Brownville to meeting & finally came back Sabbath eve, as there was prospect of a storm in the morning.  I expect Lucy was a little too smart about her Thanksgiving washing etc., 'overdid' & took cold.  Dr. Kimball came & prescribed Calomel!!  However she was much better Sunday & I guess was only a Cold & Rheumatism, and she will get over it in few days.  Charles has not done much upon the house yet.  But Mr Gilman is coming to keep him soon.  Almer Butler has been threshing:  the grain turns out most miserably.
Completed

Joseph is getting along pretty well in his school I believe. He is a good teacher, I know. He has an Indian in his school. 40 or 50 scholars. Universalist people.

 I hardly know how I am prospering. I hear some complaints of my punishing, which I have found it impossible to do without entirely. People are very ready to blame a teacher as not being strict enough, but no one is willing to have their children punished. School averages 60 & upwards, all weathers. Writing school Sat. R. M.'s Flatter myself I am a pretty good "Writing Master," if this letter does belie it.
 My school is very tiresome. I am so exhausted & lazy that I do not make out to study much evenings. I sleep 8 to 10 hours too instead of 4 to 6 as I did in the fall. Very bad habits!

Mr. Parker's folks had a "donation party", on Thurs. 21.  About 100 people there P.M. & evening. Presents amt. of 40, or 50 $.

I am anxious to hear from you. It is most two months. I show willing to pay postage once a month, at least. Eliab must write. I am ? to hear where you are & what you are doing. How does Eliab spend the winter? He must not forget his religion. Young Christians have especial need to watch. Eliab ought to be studying something.
Habits of idleness & inapplication of mind are easily formed, but thrown off with difficulty.   The state of religion is low here & seemingly everywhere about.   I hope you will write mesome good, long, oldfashioned letters, as you used to; have Eliab write, do him good. Ann too.  I wish you all a "happy

new year"!" This wish includes all friend & relatives, everybody I can remember, at least

               Your Affectionate and ever mindful son
                                                         Isaac S. Metcalf
Completed

I really wish you or someone else, would tell me what to do in the world.  I have, providence, willing , a life to spend & a living to  get, somehow, but I truly know nothing how or where. Pray who does,  It is certainly time I did.  It can hardly be the part of a reasonable man to decide on going through college now.
I suppose you are expecting a letter from me but I don't  knows as I shall be able two write you much I am writing and and cannot have any thoughts to myself because of talking it seems more than ever to me that we are located in the corner of creation here all seems to be life and animation they are mind you not all froze up mind, the Engineer is this very week surveying the rout for a railroad through this town.  The rout they are looking at now is East of uncle Jo, across the Rabbit farm and Kimball/ Whitney's & Uncle Conants, but there will be a great strife about where it shall go Greenfield folk, say it shall go through that town  or not at all.  I am now at  Maj. Gates Eben Bull teaches the school on the Crock George Greensbro' (grandson) is a small merchant has a store in the middle of the  town.
Dwight Mayor, teaching in ? but a most all the young men are ? or the rest teaching or trading or something hardly enough pay to keep the old ? good.

I want to leave school.  All the folks in Mass.  I expect we have been here away from all our 'kinsfolks and acquaintance,' for so long, as to be almost forgotten if not forgetting. Anything you write will please.  I have got a new coat made, A 'taglioni' so called, can wear over another coat generally not.  Pay Dockam $7,50 for making & trimming in the Spring.   I have borrowed five dolls. of Tash.  It is ridiculous for me to be so poor.  Too bad for a person of my abilities!  reputation! & Intrinsic worth!  To teach school for $16 dolls per month.  Especially as a tremendous hard school as this.
Isaac

Foxcroft March 3rd 1844, Sunday

Dearest Mother
My roommate's beau came this morning and staid so long that I could not get ready in season to go to meeting;  so I will sped a part of the forenoon in writing to you, although I do not in all cases approve of writing letters Sunday.  Joseph cam up with me last Monday, went to Dexter Tuesday to try to find a chance to work, but did not succeed.
to go to school.  Isaac & I board together at the Butlers;-not more than three or four roads from the Academy.  We boarded vis. Miss Kent from Sebec Isaac & myself have a comfortable, pretty little parlour (with an airtight stove, rocking settee) and two bedrooms leading from it.  My room has a fire in it.  The price of board is 8/ with washing alone, or 7/6 and do my own washing.  I think I shall do my own & Isaac's too.  Miss Caverno is very amiable, pleasant, handsome, agreeable, pretty too.  I like it a great deal better being in a room by ourselves, (we girls) but we have to go down below to write, which is grievous.  I study Algebra (and if you will believe it, get along nicely therin too; - I  was behind most of the class when I came, but am now ahead all the girls)  Upham's Mental Philosophy, Arithmetic & Grammar.  Oh dear, how I do have to "manipulate" on the board in Algebra & Arithmetic.  Isaac has the Algebra, Mr Tash Arithmetic & Miss C, Upham.  If it is a possible thing I shall get excused from going to the board, for I am so abominable silly that it takes my strength "entirely away"
[top of page upside down] This is universally acknowledged to be a very hard school. If she teaches any where about here, the school and Milo Mills will be a good one on account of high wages and tractable scholars.
Completed

it makes me as weak as a sail.  It is foolish I know, but so ill and I cannot help it.
Sunday March 10th - Again I stay at home from meeting, partly on account of a cold, and partly because the walking is very bad.  When I came from home I left cooked a turkey doughnuts, two whole hog shoulders, thirteen loaves of bread and two mince pies!  Didn't I do pretty well?  I find since I came here, that I need some kind of a handsome dress:  having nothing of the kind except my black one, and that I have had four years, and it is entirely out of fashion, besides being lined throughout so that it is uncomfortably warm in moderate weather.  My silk one is so small I cannot wear it with flannels at all.  But I don't know if there is any help for it, except to "grin and bear it."  Isaac needs a hat very much, but has not got his money yet for teaching school.  Small means!  "Great minds & small means ruin."  Not that I would insinuation that we have great minds accompanying our small means.  By no means.  I never heard Isaac declaim really in my life till last Wednesday, and he really did much better than I expected.  I laugh at him some for pursuing a College course so far before he has concluded whether to go or not.  If he is not going he had better do something else.  We may not write again before you come home & about getting anything if there is any way to get them - you know what we need I suppose.  The boys need some linen for bosoms & dickeys Isaac especially, much; and I shall have to have something in the shape of clothes very soon.  But you know best.  Aff daughter Lucy.

I don't want nothing as I see but what I can get on do without.  Isaac & Lucy have left not me much room to write I not only do but also I have got not much to write.  The school out on Stanckfield ridge, in which Isaac kept the village school long time ago was consumed by fire last Thursday night.  Daniel Barker for Exeter was keeping the school.  Gilman is at work on the house yet.  I guess expect him 2 weeks longer now.  I guess I feel sleepy & Eliab had it better a gone to Massachussetts .  I don't know what else to write.  Joseph.
[top of page upside down] The people here are very extravigant in their expressions about Ann as a good teacher, - all with one cannot want her to keep the school this summer, but if I was here I should not- she can get better schools for higher wages.
Completed

Foxcroft March 10th 184?

Dear Mother
We are all very pleasantly situated here, pleasant rooms. etc. etc.  Can step out of the back door into the Academy yard.
I am on about the same foundation as last autumn; am occupied in the regular recitations just 2 hours out of The Six, at present.
Have a very good class in Algebra, 2 in Grammar & one in Arithmetic besides a private class or so, out of school hours.
And then we are so handy here that we have an abundance of callers, of all kinds, many
come in for assistance in all branches.  I am studying "Menophon" and "Livy", on the regular college course.  I can fit, I suppose
to enter a year in advance this fall, if I try.  I have not concluded!
I am also dipping into the more extended college course of Mathematics.
I am getting along finely, can do up the regular college lessons throughout in a 
few hours per diem.  School commenced with 52 students, &
at present, constantly increasing.  Shall not have more than 100 in all_
pretty good for a Spring term.  Joseph is here now, has been ?
where to get something to do - mind is on every bit studying.
Lucy's health is not very good, perhaps not so good as it was last spring, takes cold easy.
She has been shut up in the house so all winter been out but one or twice till she came here.  No horse, at home, know.
I think her health will improve here, if she is careful, does not have to go but a step or so in bad weather & walking.
I do not believe Eliab has got along so well in study this winter as Lucy has, at home alone, I at work all the time.
She went through Smith thoroughly at home, & is getting along finely in Algebra.
will be one of the best in my class.  We rec'd a letter from Eliab via John Cutler last week or so.  When are you coming home;
I have very little faith in Eliab's going to learn a trade in Boston;
Completed

Mar. 3rd 1844

                                          Mar 11                                                                                           18 3/4

[right-hand side]Charles and Mr. Gilman are sticking to the house, have got clapboards planed & All clapboarded, all the floor boards planed, & most of the trimmings. Joseph is in a quandary whether to take the West half of Mrs. Lee's farm in front of Charles' or to buy Mr. Kleen's down river. (Mr. K. has bought Mr. Noverof's over in Atkinson where we hauled logs, moves this spring) or to go up to the iron works, or wherever.'  

 I hardly know what to do myself this summer,  at least if I do not study. I have some thought of going down to Enfield, and engaging in Treat's Carding Mill there. Treat invited me to. If I should conclude to go on with my studies,  I ought to be engaged in some lucrative business for the little time I can spare this summer. I hardly think I shall go to College after all, I suppose if not, my time is not lost by any means{} We see by Isaac's description of Joe's quandary that a little learning is a dangerous thing and that words without knowledge darken counsel. I do not hardly know whether to go to sea this spring or not. It is very rarely we hear from Milo have you
Completed

Foxcroft June 21 1844

Dear
I do not know as I have much of any thing to write just now, certainly not of importance.  I like to write letters home as well as think of home, even if I do not very often hear from these.  Things get along about as usual, and I have just got fairly settled down to my studies again, after my weeks absence, some called it running away here.  Four new scholars entered the school while I was gone,  Anna Hutchins of Industry, who was here last fall; and there young men from Charleston, who left here for some reason suddenly, right in the middle of the term.  They were, I should think their three best scholars there, nearly fitted for College, I think of going to Brunswick this fall.  I guess they are really first rate fellows & good scholars.  Isaac W. Case, Dr Case's son of Levant, James K. Bartlett of Harmony and Smart who was in Milo a year ago.  B.B Sinart, I believe.  If I go to Brunswick they will be my companions these three years, probably.
The school now numbers 42 in all!  Mr. Task did not know but he would have to set me to work again, he said, but I guess he will get along as some are leaving occasionally.
Nancy Carpenter has left. Trafton & Owens, Philbrick was gone last week, Delegate to the great Whig State Convention!
Completed

I found a letter from Joseph in the P.Q when I came up here, if Lucy had waited she might have seen it.
I suppose likely you have heard from him ere this, he wrote that he had written sent or was about to send home.
He says he is not at work in a lath mill for 10,00 per M. never saw a lath mill.  Saw window blinds & slatz, and has $13,00 per month.  He was there week before he obtained permanent employment in which he earned enough to pay his board & one cent more.
Joseph wrote that there was some probability that in a fortnight, which would be near this time, he should be at work on the Fish river road, for the state.  That I suppose is a way up to Aroostook,100 or 200 miles.
Wrote nothing of the Fish River condition or prospect except $15,00.
Our bell is not living yet, afraid it will not before the 'Fourth',  There is to be a great Democratic Celebration 
at Dover.                  Whig
at Levant,      &        Liberty
up to Parkman.  
"       "               Mr Parker I suppose delivers an adds.  I don't know yet whether I shall stay here or go home, or run off somewhere.
Court week, some important cases.  Bol. Paul 8 May Blethen at last decided in favor of Paul.  unexpected decision.
How would it work for me to go to work for Captain Holmes or some of the big farms, here in laying, for some money.  Guess I might.  James Holmes told me they wanted to hire.  I expect I have got along so I might leave my studies some.  Might work here for money spell, before Charles begins
Completed

Society meeting, this A.M.  Mr Parker went down to south Dover, funeral of Mr. Joseph Foster, a member of this Church.  P.M Mr. Parker text.  Lion is a Desolation.
The present, declaration of religion, it's causes;  finally bought in slavery, or connection of the American Church with it, as one cause;  and spoke the rest of the afternoon
upon it, or at least much longer than usual, and very good too pretty severe too, but I guess offended no one;  people here different from a few years ago.  
Mr. Parker has had a great influence  here, very great in that respect.  He is a very different man from Mr. Wells.
Fourth of July  Bell ringing & powder smoking morning.  As I swam an hour or so yesterday, worked considerable, and was employed late in the evening, I took a fine nap at the whole gun fire & bell ringing this morning.
Alot of our best uns have gone down to Levant this morning, my roommate Chandler, Philbrick, the Charleston fellows, first rate chaps they are, etc.  They had a flag made of their own 'Foxcroft Academy' 'Class of Protection'.  The others got an best motto, 'Protection and no Flag? page torn I would not go under the 'Clay'.
Got our ? page torn up yesterday.  P.M I worked to get it up, considerable job, outside.  They call it ? page torn  bell in the place.  pleasant tone.
I have received another long letter from Clark, this week
I would to Joseph again but he left me in uncertain, whether to direct to Old town or fish River.  If he wrote to you let me know.
Mr Tash', 'Fourth' excites some speculation.  (He went up to Capt. Holmes, where he is a frequent nightly visitor, one Wed eve.  & was not seen in these parts again till Thurs eve, or Fri. morn.    I staid here part of the day, I had a fine ride up to Guilford & about with Clement who was going up & offered me a ride with him.
They had quite a parade here, but I did not care for it, or for H. Hamlins' speeches.  Clay Celebration at Levant.  J. W. Case, who went down from here, read the Declaration Paine Orator.  Mr. Parker delivered an address up to Parkman.
I intend to have sent this letter by (Dr Kimball Frid. but he went too soon.
Completed

Isaac

[top of letter] I had Eliab's jacknife in my pocket, by some unaccountable mistake, when I came up from Milo, and never knew it till Lucy went back, I am afraid he wants to use it. I really wish Eliab would write to me. It is for his own interest. He must practice writing especially if he would teach. Did I ever have the Canker rash? It is ? page torn one of Mr. Young's children died of it week or two since. Little Chauncey has it now. If I should go to haying,  I want some coarse ? page torn to wear.

Brunswick Sept 6th 1844

Dear Mother and Brothers & Sisters;
I am here quietly sealed in my room sabbath day after meeting, and, as I have not before, perhaps it will be no harm to write a letter home.  Today.
I suppose you are all wishing to hear, all how I got here, how I like, & how I get along.  To begin at the beginning Eliab can  tell how we got to Bangor, & I should like to hear from him how he got back.  I don't know as it was right for him to go home so into the sabbath.  What time did he arrive?  (How does Josephs coat suit.)  You know he can send it back. I hope Eliab did not get it injured in the rain.  The fact is, I know nothing what he wanted.
He did not even tell me how much he wished to give for one, which would have been a guide you know? The one I bought was precisely of the new fashion; perhaps you will not like it.  I had only the night to pick it out in, but I guess it is a pretty coat and cheap.  It was a perfect fit for me.  Mr. Norcross jun. of the Washington House had the mate to it, just alike for $12,00 I got it, 25 cheaper for the button lost.
I went to Mr. Pomroys to tea Sunday.  AM gave me $5,00.  I heard Mr. Gough, (from Goff) Sab. Eve.  The best temperance lecturer, he has had great effect in Bangor. The young men need his influence.  It rained much Sab eve, & the wind blew all day hard.  So the steamboat passage was very rough & I was a good deal seasick:  I omitted to lay in provisions Sat, and had to get breakfast on board or I should have perished almost.  The aggravations of
seasickness, are increased tenfold by an empty stomach.
The only cure is eating I suffered much for dinner
Completed

Mr Gough was on board & gave us a speech down the bay.
He lectured here Wed.Eve.  We arrived at Portland at dark, two hours late for the extreme sea roughness.
Had to pay, 163 for carrying my trunks to a tavern, & ,25 for my lodging alone.  Supper & breakfast both, 12 1/2.  Got to Brunswick in
the stage for $1,00, which was better than to walk, as I probably could not get the trunks carried for 50

 It is perhaps a bad thing for Clark that I did not come the week before as I intended.  He concluded I should not come, and cared he could not get another room mate which would double his bills of rent, fuel, lights. The day before I came, when he had about given up seeing me;  book, one of last spring term associates, came & wanted to go in with him (Clark is popular) and would buy some nicer furniture.  Under the circumstances, I thought not best to interrupt them though they both offered to.  Cook is rather a Rowdy acquired considerable reputation in the "Bagger war??" last spring by "knocking down" a "Bagger" in the street, & day time for which however he was 'Suspended' a while.
I do not think his influence beneficial upon Clark, who is one of those characters who take their stamp from the company they keep in a great degree.

I had however several other chances offered me.  Among the rest, a certain Senior, James Newton by name wanted I should come in with him for this term, as his chum is absent. It would save him half of fuel & lights.  It was a pretty good as his room is well furnished; but it would be going out of my class, which is unpleasant, & I must find a new room mate. Set up for myself in the spring, which would be more difficult.      His object was said to be to make
Completed

me a Peucinian, as he is a member of that society. 

  I have been the past week with a Mr. Baker Wm. W a sophomore, just come from Waterville, Belfast fellow.  He is a good clever fellow, a beneficiary, stout, slow, but perhaps strong, might make a good chum, without being a very popular student.
   I have bought me a cap, same material as Josephs', but large, big top, & fixed off, quite a cap, for $1,00. Bought at Griffin, the College Monopolist.  Guizot $1,10, French grammar, 70, Cic. Sen. Am, 55, Hom Iliad 1,15.  Total of $3,50 on term bill.  Legendses Geometry I bought second hand for $.50, price 1.25.  I ought to have brought Boyer with me.  New one costs $2,25, borrowed Newton for this term.  Our duties are, Bell about ? page torn  Prayers in the little old crowded chapel.  Recitation, ? page torn weekly, Cic. Am. Latin, & Homer Greek, Latin is very easy, & Greek will be when get underweigh. Next, BreakfastAnn spoken & Homer Greet Latin is very easy, Green will be when get underweigh, next, Breakfast 
 At 9, Study hours, everyone required to be in rooms. 11, Rec, in Geometry, very easy so far.  Dinner 2, Study hours, 4 French, on which Prof. Goodwin drills us till prayer bell, double time, about.  This is the hardest study to me.  Drives hardest.  probly because I lost 3 or 4 lessons, which it is very difficult to gain, that is the instructions of Prof. G at recitations.  Pronouncing & cogitating verbs I think hard.  (grows easier very fast)

On the  whole I am getting on finely & expect to.
I am very much obliged to Ann for her loan, under the circumstances might have been short without it.
I hope you will all take pains & write.
I.S. Metcalf.
Completed
