Total Expenses $280,00   Since Sept. 1, 1844

"      Receipts  " 240,00   about 18 months


Debt                $       40,00  Most of which I now owe on my College Term bills, but about $25.00 of which I do not mean to pay at all, being that for Advance Standing. It is rather discouraging  after being absent from College for near six months, earning money. & economical as I have been, and then find onesself $40.00 in debt.  However not so bad as it might be, supplied with many times twice the money, are much in debt at stores etc. I do not get in debt and only on term bills & those can run. I shall earn this term by building fires etc. etc. some $15. or 20.00, which will keep the term bill along somewhat. Somehow I expect to have some money the first of June to pay for Board bills & incidentals, say $25.00.
If Charles can help me to it - good, if not perhaps I can borrow it of Joseph as I did last summer. If I have my health, & the blessing of Providence, and  do not get too deep into Society Expenses, I shall be better as well off next spring as this.
Perhaps, under all most favorable aspects,  and uniform good fortune & health, might get through College by only borrowing $100,00 to pay my Graduating Expenses!

 I have been extremely economical: can't tell for the future. May yet spend $50.00 for term for societies.  I cannot be mean.  I think I have done pretty well in dress. $60, or $70,00 is allowed per annum to dress a young man.  I have spent $60,00 in 18 months. Had hardly any thing at first. Now can dress decently, pretty good suit of clothes, Cloak etc.  Do write.    I.S.M.
Completed

Bowd. Coll. March . 15th , 1846

Dear Mother

                 Your last excellent letter of March 1st or 7th was thankfully received by me about a week since, March 9th.  You can hardly imagine how much good it does me to get hold of a letter from you. Seems to me you give up the matter of writing to you children! most too much to Lucy.  I am sure I like to receive letters from Lucy right well, and should be very glad if she would write twice as often & much, but I do not want you should depend entirely upon her, so as not to write at all yourself.
 I am glad you happened to write upon your birthday, for I am sure I did not know when it was before, now I will remember. I have a very poor memory of dates and numbers. I know no one's birth day but my own, I guess.

But I did not think you were quite so old as 59 though. It seems longer to me than to you though, although I realize that each succeeding year seems to me shorter than the preceding. 

I am afraid my letters will begin to be troublesome to you, at any rate I guess you will not have time to read them all, if they come half a dozen at a time; Especially if they are such a foolish scribbled  mess of empty words as some of the last I have sent. At any rate, if you could not find out what they meant, it would be no great loss any way.
Completed

I am very much obliged to you for writing a few particulars about matters and things, and wish you had tenfold more. You cannot think how interesting such thing are to me, how I have wanted to hear about all such things for a whole year past, and could hardly get a word from any of you. How I should like to see all the things! for instance those colts. It seems Charles now likes the red one the best, I always did, but he always used to have a curious prejudice for the little grey, just as he used to for the little steer, perhaps because he was so chunked. How much does he prize the Donkey at? We will never sell him for $100.00 I suspect.

 As for my poverty it is vexatious enough I assure you, but I have made up my mind not to suffer myself to be much disturbed by it. I can get along somehow, as others do. I can without running in debt as others, some others do: I will be: and am economical about useless things. I will not spend $100, per term in riding about, or $20,00 in Cigars, or in going to balls, shows & parties, or more get in drunken sprees.
But as for the Societies, I am in for it, and I will not back out. I never have been naturally disposed to be very active in such meetings. Every one knows I am not ambitious, not enough so for my own interest in College, or any where else, or for my friends. But here circumstances have drawn me in to it, and I will play a Major part and do it manfully, assured that I am right, and that however I may be slandered in my reputation, assailed by those whose interest it is, as will surely be the case, yet it will all come out right in the end, trusting in right, truth, and true hearted friends. There is a good deal of excitement in College growing out of these Secret Societies at present. The contest
Completed

I will tell you what it is about it. A.B. C. F. M. It has been remarked that great mean are not always wise. It is still more true that worldly wisdom sometimes carries great men out of the path of simple straight forward truth & right. They become too nice to see that it is the best policy. Expediency is a great God. At meeting of the A.B.C.F.M. last Fall, the Great Men, Dr. Woods of Andover, Dea Beecher, Stowe & Anderson etc. big guns, were set to make a report on the great Slavery question, much agitating the country, & threatening to divide the Board.  It was a great duty. They felt it. The interests of the country & the world were on them. They were Great men, mighty men; but their souls were not big enough They feared the face of man, trusted not in God, and bowed down to the God Expediency.  They made a report. It was a master peice. It spake of Organic & inorganic sins; a cunning theory. To the Northern Man it was an Antislavery document: to the Southern Man it sanctioned Slavery in toto. It was designed to unite all parties, the plan apparently succeeded. The board were, it was said unanimous. The lesser lights dared not shine. But - the craven northerners dodged.  They probably feared Expediency also. At any rate, out of some hundreds of Northern & Eastern men present, only a dozen or two signed the report. Moreover most of those who signed the report were immediately elected Corporate members of the Am Board, none of the others!

 But the matter could not rest there, some thing cannot be covered up even by Leonard Woods D.D.  et cum suo.   
  Woods & Co doubtless thought their wisdom would be for "the greatest good of the greatest number." it was the very difficulty. They should have thought what is morally right, conform wisdom to that, not that to wisdom: and let Him whose right it is take care of the consequences. 
                                         Do write to your Son I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Is it a fact that you do not even have a Newspaper there. You ought to have some books also. The books there are all so ? few are worth reading nowadays. I wish I could carry you home some. Here a great trouble is so many We have perhaps 20000 to volumes to select reading from.

  As for my clothing, I intend to dress well in future whether or not, that is decently, or rather, always have one decent suit. Clothing does make an odds, there is no mistake about that. I found it at Turner when I went there I had a new coat, & could dress decently.
   I have changed my Chum this year. First year I roomed with Wm. M. Baker of Belfast, a beneficiary of the Ed. Soc. A good fellow & fine scholar. We joined different Societies all round. He is a Peucinian & a VV. We thought best to separate. The VV wished him to go with them, room with one of them who needed steadying, & a good scholar at his elbow!  My Chum this year is Sam'l W. Hatch of Bowdoinham, 12 miles from here. A Methodist, going to be a Methodist Minister, and a stout one too, if he lives and has his health. He a Peucinian, but a Brother DKE Delta Kappa Epsilon.
 Mr. Chickering of Portland preached here yesterday, most excellent sermons, adapted for Students too, did them good.
 The new church is to be Dedicated next Wednesday March 18th It is the most splendid affair in the state. I never saw it like. How I wish you could only just see it. I expect the Dedication will be a great day. Wonder if the big house will be filled.
  I wrote to Joseph requesting if convenient that he or some one would send me $10,00, as I am entirely out.
Completed

against YV, overbearing aristocracy of money, & good fellowism, and genteel disposition, is, in a great measure, to be fought this year. But there are strong fellows to fight it.

  The whole torrent this spring has been to 'put down' ΔΚΕ, to run it by any means no matter how, private & public, individual & general; open & concealed, malice & scorn, lies & sneers. - but all originated in fear. But all will not do: truth must prevail.  The yearly Class Election of Orator & Poet in the Sophomore Class took place last Friday. 

The candidates for Orator were the ΨΥ Stevens, the big gun of the Class, the great man of ΨΥ and my good friend & Brother Case of Levant.  It was hard contested and great excitement. One would think the very existence of ΨΥ depended upon Stevens election. Even the Seniors interested themselves in it, electioneered for them. On our side, the Sophomores worked it out for themselves, in all ?houses? Case was Elected. 18 to 17 One majority.  It was justly considered a victory, little to be sure, but a beginning. It is secretly called an omen that Metcalf will be next President of the Athenaean Society! 

  The defeat did not set very well upon the ΨΥ. They made a terrible outcry, in their anger brought a raving charge of Lying etc. against a ΔΚΕ. He defended himself calmly, and with so much true courage that they could not get him to fight, and finally they were obliged to take back and apologize! It was rich. They over did themselves.
                I would write to Uncle Joseph, if  I knew how. How I should like to go to Mass.  Probably I shall not go to 'Oregon', if the Mormons do, at least till they die off. 

As for the Doctor project I was in earnest then, though in truth, I am so busy since, I do not think about it.  As for Uncle Natty, I will do nothing but let him alone, & pray you too.
Completed

Bowd. Coll. Apr. 5th ' 46

Dear Mother

             I have written a whole lot of letters to send to Bangor by James Newton and some of them may perhaps get to Milo some time or other; though I do not know as they will be worth the reading.
 One thing - I have forget what it was though- I had a letter from Lucy the other day, but not a single word from dear Mother. I wish you would write oftener. 
  I am getting along well as could be expected I believe. Have made up all my studies and stand as well as the rest of my class.

getting along now as east as need be.
My health is now first rate: though I have lost a little flesh I expect since I came back to College. It has been quite unhealthy here as well as every where else. Week before last, the week that it rained so, you remember. I was somewhat unwell, did not go out of my room much for three days, it rained. They said I was threatened with the Scarlet Fever which prevailed some, but I took no remedies of any kind, and felt well as soon as it came fair weather and the sun
Completed

shone on me. I am blessed with good health, more than many most others.

We have lately got up a Bible Class Sabbath afternoons, and got Prof. Goodwin to take charge of it. It bids fair to be very interesting. Prof. G. is a very deep thinker and a man of great erudition also, and very critical, and at the same time common sense. Qualities not always united.
  I shall probably be in Bangor about the 20th or 21st of May. Will it be convenient for C to be down there any time then and carry me up. Or I can walk up just as well perhaps and send my trunk up perhaps. Or possibly I may conclude to go across the country from up to Waterville. The Foxcroft fellows think some of having a horse & waggon come over to Waterville and carry them home.
 However time enough a month hence to make arrangements for getting home though I begin to think of it some already.
 It seems too as if the fortnight was a dreadful short time to be at home, after so long absence, 15 months, and perhaps not likely to see there again for so long. for very probably it will not be convenient for me to get home again till about the time I graduate, on the Senior Vacation.
Completed

Rev. Nr. Burk a converted Jew from Poland lectures tonight at meeting. I must go down and hear him and carry the letters and give to Newton, as he goes tomorrow morn.

 I do not know as I have any thing to write and what I have written or scribbled if it could be read, would not be worth reading.
 However you must take the will for the deed, and write to me soon.
Let me know all how you get along at home
                                                                             Your Affectionate Son
                                                                                                                  I.S. Metcalf

You can see the haste and excuse.
Completed

Bowd. Coll. May 7th 1846

Dear Mother

   I received your last letter about a week since I think. I have not much to write now. except to tell when I expect to get home. What with 'Nostalgia,' or at least desire to go home, and the length of the term & hard study, I have got rather tired out.
  I believe I should have started for home by this time, in spite of my dislike at making up and being Examined at the beginning of the term; if it were not that I have the bell to ring and cannot very well get away.
 I do not see how I can get along with staying at home only a fortnight, and yet I do not see but I must be back here about the beginning of the term.
 I shall have considerable business, as Treas. of the Ath. Soc. that must or ought to be done first week of the term. Besides it is just before Election, and time then you know is important & valuable.
 Our Examination Wed. May 20th, I suppose but, as the boats now run, if one staid here
Completed

till after Tuesday night, he cannot go to Bangor by steamboat till Friday night, arrive there Sat. 10 A.M.  So I am determined not to wait. I shall go to Proffessors and request to be examined on Tuesday, if they refuse, I shall take the responsibility and start off Tuesday night. so as to be in Bangor Wed. Morn May 21st at 10 A.M.

 It is possible that the Boats may make some new arrangements before that time so that I may wait till the next day.
  I rather think they will not refuse to examine me on Tues. if they do, I do not care.
 You say, get my Daguerreotype taken. I should like right well to, but, in my circumstances, I do not know as it will do for me to.
  I am sorry Lucy keep school up there in Hol town almost. could she get no other better chance?
  I shall bring home a big lot of old clothes, I can assure you. Some, perhaps but few that will be worth mending.
  I suppose I ought to have some linen made up, bosoms, I have pretty some collars. Ann sent me bosom by Ed. Brown, but it though a pretty good one, was hardly large enough for me as they wear Vests now, and
Completed

I should like some of rather finer linen, the bosom you know is that part of the dress most in sight  Have you any patterns of such as are worn nowadays?

  I do not know but it would be the cheapest way to buy such things ready made.
  It is now about 15 months since I have been at home, and it is very possible that I may not be at home again for about as long, if I teach fall & winter, till Senior Vacation, July 1849 just before I graduate.
         Lucy must dismiss her school for last week at least, while I am at home but two weeks though.
  I do not think if any thing more to Say. hope to come home & say it, if I have.
    Be in Bangor Wed May 20th, and for myself might walk to Milo
                   Your Aff. Son I.S. Metcalf

P.S.  Been a whole 1/2 hour writing this!
Completed

Bowd. Coll. June 14th 1846.

Dear Mother

          I suppose you are somewhat anxious to hear from me, not knowing exactly how I was to get home. I therefore undertake to write without delay.  Charles, I suppose, told you how I was left by Clark, because he could not get any horse to come with; and also how he carried me most over to Dexter, and then consigned me to Esq. Robinson, who kindly furthered me to Dexter, where I arrived a little after 5 P.M.  By the way, what time did Charles get home that night? I do not believe he finished sheep shearing the next day.
  There was no Stage went from Dexter until Thursday noon, 42 hours. I should have gone right on foot, but I hated to leave my trunk behind, for it is not a direct route to Waterville by Stage. two crop routes, up to Skowegan, & then down to Waterville, making near 60 miles, while it is 38 40 by direct route. If I left trunk & come by Stage, it would only get to Waterville Friday noon, & I should be lucky if it ever got from there to Brunswick. Besides I found that there was very much direct communication from Dexter to Waterville, chances to go or send very often. Only two hours before I arrived there, two teams started for Waterville.
  So I waited at Dexter until Wednesday 3 1/2 oclock P.M. before I had chance to leave there. Expense$,62 1/2 A man going over started them, that I expected would go in the morning, fine team, went within 4 miles of Waterville that
Completed

evening, stopped in early in the morning. Fare $2,37 1/2. Stage would have been $2,50 & much harder every way. Lodging & breakfast, 3 1/2. Staid at Waterville 2 or 3 hours, seeing Colleges & some old acquaintances, but little business for lack of Coadjutors. 9 A.M. Went to Augusta 18 ms. in Steamer Fare ,25. 11 oclock Kennebec Dam just repairing, lock not fixed. Walked round Augusta, State House etc. heard part of a great speech on Colburn of Belfast, contested seat, which I thought was decided week before. Walked down to Hallowell, awful heat. Steamboat at Kennebec at 2 1/2 PM to Bath, Fare, 50 arrived there 5 P.M. Called at Mr. Sewall's, Susan Carpenter's husband.  Sewall is a rich real estate holder. plain good sort of a man.  They were very glad to see any one from Foxcroft. Stopped there to Supper. Mr. Sewall happened to be obliged to harness his horse, and insisted upon carrying me half way up to Brunswick.  I did not want him to, but I suppose it was a good thing. You see he is to lazy to harness the horse often, and it really suffers for exercise. I really pitied the poor thing, it is very large indeed, heaviest horse in Bath, and Mountain of flesh, so far it could hardly get along.

  Arrived at College at 10 P.M. Thursday, June 11th, some what tired but well as Metcalfe, having had a very pleasant, and cheap journey.  Clark arrived perhaps twenty four hours sooner, having come all the way through in the stage, probably cost him considerable more than me, and had much harder time if it every way.
Completed

Things are getting on here much as usual, considerable excitement about the elections, and increasing. I have not studied much yet,too much business to attend to, only go into recitations, though aught to study, make up for absence.
By the way, when I left Charles he gave me $15.00 I believe; wanted to more, but I refused to take it. I had calculated just how much I had to spend, and found that I could get along with that, $30.00 it would make, for this term.  Was it because I refused money when I could have it? When I arrived here, I found an old bill against me as Steward of boarding Club, which by some one's carelessness, possibly mine, though I think not, in fact know it, had been mislaid.  It is against me, and I of course pay it. It is $10 to 12?
 The Club would of course contribute to pay it, but the word obscured boarded there that term, it was last summer, were about all Senior, and now gone.  I will not call upon the 3 or 4 only now here to help pay it. I do not hardly know what I can shall do about it. If Charles had that money still, I would not refuse it again! If C has not, perhaps I can borrow it, for a month or two, or maybe get it of Jos. or Eliab.
  I wish Charles would take measures to sell Donkey I fear me he is getting off the notion of it, very bad so to do.
 Has that Garden been planted yet?! What is Charles doing about Haying work? (Do now write me all about every thing. I wonder if Lucy is at home today; how I want to see you all! I declare I am almost homesick!

Do write to                                                           Isaac
Completed

I.S. Metcalf Bowd.
July 20 '46                                                                                               Bowd. Coll. July 19th 1846
Dear Mother     

                        How would it do for me to begin to grumble, and say that I have been six weeks away from home, and Mother had not written a word to me? I had almost begin to think you had all forgotten me; it was about five weeks before I heard a single word from any one either at Milo or Bangor. I have however now received a nice letter from Sister Lucy, and when Young Weld came on, last week, I got a letter from Joseph, but not a word from Anne or Eliab

Miss Weld returned to Bangor, the 17th inst. I sent by her a letter to Joseph, and also one I had written to Lucy. I do not know when it will get to Milo, an perhaps not much Matter.

 I hardly know why I write this letter just at this present time, except it be to say, that if Charles succeeds in selling his Colt, (and I think he had better, if possible, at any decent rate) I wish he would let me have some of the money, if he can. If he cannot, or does not, I must make some arrangement with Joseph, or somehow, so as to have some at command next term.
Completed

I ought to have $50,00 st least, at the beginning of the next term, and then should remain a good deal indebted upon my term bills; but I suppose I can get along and be satisfied with $25.00. by plunging a little deeper in debt; for which however I care not, for, if I have my health & God's blessing, I can earn it by Spring.  I do not yet know what I shall do this fall, probably either a school here in Brunswick, or else go to Turner as last Fall; though it is altogether too bad to be out of College for $20,00 per month, a Senior too.

 I ought to have some better chance than either, and deserve it, according to what some others succeed in doing.
 Joseph wrote merely that Charles had been making some "ineffectual"efforts to sell the Blk Colt.  I thought from Lucy's letter that he was somewhat likely to succeed in selling somehow.
  I must tell you of the scrape we got into last week. We Juniors have no Recitation Wed. P.M. Theme day. Last Wed. 15th, fifteen of us went down to the Bay to have a 'sail.' four miles. 2 oclock, intending to get back by 6.  Got a sail boat of perhaps 10 or 12 Tons burthen. Wind south, beat against it out several miles, thinking we could come
Completed

back shortly any time. Wind died away, Tide began to set down the bay strong. Breeze sprang up right off shore. Schooner Lily a poor sailor 'on a wind.' Began to get hungry, nothing a mouthful to eat or drink! Decided to put away for the 'Mansion House 15 miles from here. Harpowell. Arrived there at 10 P.M. After some trouble mooring out 'bonny bark', and getting ashore.  we set people to work, and did ample justice to the best fare the place afforded, before midnight . High time. 

Next day. Bathed, Fished, Sailed, Rolled Ten Pins etc. etc. till after dinner. Found Money enough in the company to pay Eaton of the Mansion House, (which by the way is a splendid place, well kept) some $12,00 or $15,00.  After Noon breeze sprang up, and we had a splendid sail back, got home by 6, or 7  oclock P.M.
  Take it all around we had a splendid time and none the less so far being unexpected. We did not know what kind of a scrape we should have with the College for running away, expected admonition perhaps at least. But went before they had time to call us up, and told them our story, and Kellogg, Minister of Harpswell, a great friend of Students, was up, and spoke a word for us, and they let it all pass.
Completed

There was some alarm and conjecture, in College, as to what had become of us, you may imagine. More than half a class.
  Cost perhaps $2,00 apeice,
 It is too bad for me to be poor. I do like to spend money, and cannot well be mean.  I can see every year, every term, as my tastes become more refined and better cultivated, and enlarged, I cannot get along without spending more money.

However thank God, I am able to earn money for myself to spend.

 I do want much to know how Charles gets along with his haying. How I should like to be at home and help him. I wonder if he has no help but that little fellow. Do some of you write to me all about it, and all other affairs.
  How is Eliab's health?  How I should enjoy 'work' if I could be at home. instead of 'shut up to 'study', this warm weather. It is not what Man is made for. 

Do write                            I.S.
[upside down] What shall I do for money?
I have got to write a prize theme within about a Well If I am appointed on Prize Declamation, I ought to have, perhaps must have new suit of Clothes.
Completed

Bowd. Coll. July 30th 1846

Dear Mother

  I received your excellent letter this morning, and much good it did me too. I do wish you would write oftener than you do. In proof that I mean to do my part in writing well, I will at least begin a letter tonight; perhaps send it tomorrow as I am now expecting to go up to Turner tomorrow afternoon, to see about that school, up there, and may not be back till next week.   It seems that after Lucy's letter of July 7th, containing the money, you did not hear from me for some time. I wrote in a day or two after two letters and sent to Joseph by Miss Weld; perhaps he did not get them immediately, or did not have an opportunity to send Lucy's to her. I write again to Mother, on July 20th, and to Lucy at La Grange the 24th. Whether I mentioned the rec't of the money in the last letters or not,I forget.
  It appears that Eliab went home the 10th inst. He ought to have come home sooner, and must be more careful in future of his health. Be careful of him, and not let him expose himself before he is fully recovered, not let him go down to the Mills and get tired.
I shall be extremely anxious to hear from him again very soon
Completed

I am glad Lucy is getting along so well in her school. and hoe she will write again soon as she finds my letter of the 26th
Do not be alarmed about my health. It is first rate. I am hearty, fat and rugged. The hot weather is hard, but you may be assured that I do not study to hurt myself. The hot weather does not affect me badly, if I can get to the water, and sleep on the floor! besides you know I am careful about my health. You should rather talk to some of the rest of your children about being careful. I am careful naturally, as well as habitually.
  How in the world is Charles going to get all his hay? And only that little boy to help him. I should think he must have more help or it would take him till next December.
 Only got in 8 loads! That though was the 21st only.
  I do not hardly believe he will succeed in selling his colt, after all the business.
 Well if I got to Turner, I believe I shall do as every body else does.  Tic. Get suit of clothes and what ever else I want on credit and let it slide. College, board, and all bills together. Many have let their bills run for year or more.
  Moreover my credit here is pretty good, for contrary to all custom, I have gone on the cash principle with every thing but College Term Bills.
If I am not here, of course they will wait for me.
Completed

You ask if there are not many trials in being treated with contempt for the lack of the 'Almighty-dollar', of course, much; but not so much among Students themselves. Among Students generally it is not money, but worth, to be sure, they may reckon worth after different & odd standards, but wealth alone is not it. But I must say that as much cannot be said for the College government.  It is not young men that worship the dollar. I have got pretty well disgusted with College government.  I doubt much if they ever get me on their Stage. if I have to start for Wisconsin or Oregon before Commencement '47 to avoid it.  There is no mistake about it. the monied fellow has much the advantage with them, as in fact every where else in the world.  One can see it in every thing, recitation, lectures, priveleges etc.

  They must secure you know the favor & the influence of the wealthy and the great. No matter for the injuries or complaint of those not big enough to make any noise.  choke them off.
  You say you cannot write much. Why not? If you have not pen & ink, you ought to have, and time enough too to write to your children.

Do write to me often. Make Eliab write me a long letter before he goes back to Bangor; it will do him good. He is the negligent. He has not written to me- I hardly know when.                                          I wish you all know how much I want to know how every thing gets along there at home. How I should like to help Charles cut that hay.   I'll stop and put this in P.O.                              Do write to I.S.
Completed

I.S.Metcalf Bowd.
    July 9 '46
                                                                                                       Bowd. Coll. Aug. 9th 1846

Dear Mother

                   I should think you might all conclude that I do not mean to be considered a neglectful correspondent, however careless and worthless my letters may be. I believe I have written at least a dozen full letters to 'the family,' within eight weeks past. Enough surely, without they were better! In answer the them, I have received in all five!  hardly the usual proportion.  This too in term when I have had so very much of every thing to attend to, of my own business and studies and every bodie's else. I have not even had time to write my regular College themes. until three or four days past, when taking advantage of a little respite and two or three 'adjourns,' I have elaborated about a dozen solid pages of Theme.
 However I owe an apology for writing letters home so carelessly as I do. When one writes a letter home, in a hurry, the mind wearied by study and thoughtful writing, he is most apt, of not more careful than I usually am, to merely scrible of what comes up first, a mass of words, without much thought or sense.
Completed

I received a day or two since a letter from Joseph from his "quiet chamber, surrounded by books etc.", filled with grave speculations and 'well founded opinions' on various subjects, and then, crowded into the last line, these words.  "It is the Erysipelas, you must keep it in a horizontal position & constantly bathed in spirit & water said Dr. McR. when I showed him my swelled legs. J.M. Metcalf", and no other word about himself, or Anne or Eliab. I infer that he is confined to his room, and am somewhat provoked at him for not writing something of it.
I am very anxious to how both he and Eliab do.

      I went up to Turner about a week ago, started Friday night at 5 P.M. Got back at 12, Sat. night. A fellow student went with me, for whom I obtained one of the Turner schools, and who paid most of the expenses of the journey.  I have agreed to go to Turner this fall, with the privelege, if I choose, of procuring a substitute, and leaving after the first six weeks.  I shall go there the very first of September, six weeks be out before the middle of October. So that I can take the school here in Brunswick, or any other, 4 or 5 months long, thereafter. I may get the school here in Brunswick, but they will not here engage teachers so early. It would be no small advantage to be here in Brunswick through the winter, with the keys of the libraries at command, and, as I should have, all the periodicals, reviews, magazines, etc. of the Athenaean Soc. left in my charge.
Completed

But it is very doubtful. I ought not to depend upon it. So I am a candidate for a good School 25, to 30, dollars per Month, anywhere. if Down east. so I could go home, so much the better.

  Going right off so, as soon as this term closes, and not to be here at the beginning of the Next I am going to be entirely independent of the 'Mammon'. I can get some clothes, my necessary books etc. get whatever I must have in short, on tick, as others do, and pay when I come back, if it is not until next Febuary or March.  Then, if I have my health, and succeed as well this winter as 'maybe be expected' I shall be able to get along comfortably until next August or September. When, if I could borrow a hundred dollars, I could probably graduate from Bowdoin College, A.B. etc. !!!
 However, I have about made up my mind a whole year beforehand, not to perform at Commencement: which will save some considerable. The fact is, Nature and right, made me, my class being as it is, to take, as a scholar, the highest rank among them : Mind, I say as a mere scholar, not in other things. Circumstances prevent me from taking that rank on College Rank books. 

Knowing this, I am too proud to go on the stage with any part which the Faculty of Bowd. Coll. according to their ranking system would assign to me. So I judge.
Completed

Do you ask what the preventing circumstances are? It is easy to name some of them. One, enough in itself, losing one whole year of the College course. for being absent, is, for all discipline and real benefit, the same as full loss. 
Second, being absent from College one third at least of of the remainder of the course. One may study out or 'make it up' as it is called. They can easily do it so as to keep along with their class, but as a general thing, they lose it all, after all.
Moreover, there is no denying it, a person's name and station does make a difference, not so much with students, they are not old enough, not trained in this world's ways enough, to judge so, but with higher powers. A 'novus homo', as we should say in latin, new man, that is one from an unknown family, without a shadow of the claim, (it is, must be, a claim in this world,) which is bestowed by wealth, influence, power, name of family, friends, connecting, cannot expect to get along so easy. Whatever he gets in this world, he must get with a strong hand of his own; where ever he gets, he must get by hard crowding himself there. The world is against him.
The College powers must go on these same principles they must do as the world do, they are dependent on that world. It is the support of that wealth, influence, and family which supports them. they must consider this thing. I do not know but it is their duty to, At any rate they do
Completed

Continuation

It may be asked, is it it not possible, and is it not duty, to burst through these opposing circumstances, only rising, in might of true strength & genius, more vigorous for the weight of difficulties. Some, might, in themselves and favored by Providence, have done it. They are the true heroes of this world. But whether I.S. Metcalf is the man to do it is a very, very different thing.

To be sure, to try in every one's duty. I do confess my fault in not trying harder. Still, it is but little use for any but the real great man. to struggle against impossibilities! Moreover I am most essentially lacking in two things absolutely necessary.  All-grasping Ambition for the self goading stimulus, and indomitable energy to carry it out a constitutional defect. 

 I believe the intention with which I begun this letter was to write that if you wanted to send any bundle to me this fall, there would be no chance by the boys at Bangor, through those I could name them, about the last week of September. But come to think of the matter, I do not know as there is any thing I need before next spring, except such as I hope you will send often by Mail, - letters.

I left some papers at home though which I should much like, if not some books, though probably they are hardly worth the sending.
P.S. just received a nice letter from Lucy. complains that she does not hear from Milo. I want much to hear myself. from all. Eliab & Jos. health especially
Completed

I.S. Metcalf Bowd.

 Aug. 12 '46

[post mark]BRUNSWICK ME AUG 10                                       5

                      Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf                                                 
                                       Milo
                                         Maine

[right-hand side]When I went up to Turner I went out into the field and pitched on a load of hay. I am stout rugged enough this summer. How I then wanted then to take hold and help Charles at home a week or two. Do. pray. Do write all how he gets along. I really vex myself considerable about it. I am afraid he will have as bad a time as last year. Do write to me.  If Eliab has not gone,  Use your Motherly authority to have him write.   Aff.  I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Bowd. College Aug. 13th, 1846

Dear Mother, I have just received your letter of the 10th inst. and thank-you for it.

 It is a little strange that my last letter should put you into such a ferment. I wish I had kept a copy of the letter so as to see what I did write. I was not aware that the letter contained any more than I said while at home.

You must have supposed that I meaned more than I said, instead of, as is usually the case with me, saying full as much as I mean.

 I have certainly not the slightest idea of leaving to go to another College: not though as you hint, because I could not! "Leonard's" certificate of my standing, week from next Tuesday, would admit me with all honor into the Senior Class of any College in the U.S., Yale or Harvard either.  But, of course, I have no reason to leave, nothing to gain by leaving. I prefer a Diploma from Bowd. Coll. to one from any College in the U.S. except old Yale, and that I do not care much and to go there Senior would cost some $200, or 300, more, besides that I would not, on ant account, or for any consideration possible hardly. leave ' my own class and all my connections with old Bowdoin.
As for my deciding not to perform at Commencement it is only this, you may decide whether I am right or not.
Completed

circumstances prevent my taking what, in other circumstances, my talents as a scholar and my rank among my fellows, would unquestionably entitle me to, the for? highest rank in my class, that is one of the Orations at Commencement; now I decide, as others for various and less reasons do, not having such part as my rank among my fellows would otherwise entitle me to, not to perform one of the inferior parts, merely to get excused, and take my degree in honorable silence, as the majority of every class usually do. 

 I had just got so fa when I happened to think it was probably not my last letter, of Aug. 10th,that you were talking about, as you could not have received it then. I do not know what you will say to that I think that it was in that I wrote a long 'tirade,' as Lucy calls it. upon these subjects.
 However I guess I will finish this sheet and send it.
 As for my rank as a Scholar, it is, as I have said, circumstances only, enough of them to, ill preparation, late entering, and much absence, circumstances what have prevented me from taking the highest rank in my class. Still my rank is not low. It is not the highest, it is a second place; though I am considered as a fellow of some mind, and who can get his lessons or any thing else as well as others. Moreover, many is the hard lesson or hard problem that I have got out for the "rankers." some of them. I believe I am neither "Dull, Stupid, Boorish, or deficient in natural abilities," 'Lazy' I rather expect that I am
Completed

What I wrote about the influence of family & standing with the College Government, Proffessors etc. I intended only as the statement of a general truth, not meaning particularly any application to myself. I do not know but I am treated about as well as could be expected under the circumstances, being "novus homo" et pauper.

 I was hardly even blaming the 'Faculty' there for As this world goes, they must do so : it may be their duty, that is duty to themselves & the College, to do so. Still its operation is rather hard upon those who most need encouragement and protection, helping those who need no such help. 
 I believe that I wrote before that I am going to Turner, the first of September or before. If not I should have much liked to go to Mass. in vacation I think it would do me good to see the "land of my fathers", even if I found there no friends. 
 As for money, it is any time one of the most convenient things for a person in any circumstances imaginable, but, if I do well this winter, I think of rubbing on with out except my wages, until next August, or so. That is, if I can once get out of Brunswick fortnight hence. I suppose I am now indebt near $100.00 

I have received letters from Eliab, Luct, & Joseph, within a week or two. All doing well apparently. I tell you what it is, Mother, 'considering' the advantages your children have had, You have for a "likely family," no mistake, if I.S. is among them. I only wish they had some of the 'fixins', some of their imperious waste!  Write soon, Anne write, Mother write. Aff. I.S.
Completed

I.S. Metcalf Bowd.
Aug 16 ' 46

                                                                               Milo

15th
I wish you would write again soon, next week, lest I be gone to Turner Junior Examination is a week from next Tuesday Aug. 25th That night. 10 P.M. I shall probably take supper with a part of my class in or near Portland. Go to Turner the last of the week.

Topsham, Sept. 6th , 1846

My Dear Mother

                 It is Sabbath morning, but I believe I must write a little to you, just to let you know where I am etc.

I have written once or twice since receiving a letter from Milo I think, but as I wrote last that I was going to Turner a week before this, it is very probable that you have directed letter there which I have not yet received.  I wrote that I should probably go to Turner before Commencement . I have had that school on my hands ever since last Fall but this Summer, went up and made arrangements by which I could go there & leave just when I chose. having another supply my place. I then expected to have a school here in Brunswick beginning in October, and so go to Turner before Comm. and stay six weeks first. But I found myself obliged to stay at College until after Commencement, partly to help entertain company here from other Colleges, and partly to decide more exactly about the schools. Last week the Topsham Board decided to have their school school begin six weeks earlier, that is tomorrow, and continue five or six months.
[left-hand side] I guess I am in debt in Brunswick or should be in three weeks more than $100.00! $60.00 on term bills and must have a new coat etc. soon $16.00 Must dress better here than off somewhere you know. However I guess my creditors must wait as others do until I get the money Where shall I get $100.00 next August? To quit College upon.
Completed

So I must give up going to Turner at all, or else lose my situation here for all Winter. 

Fortunately, I found a good teacher to take my place there, and packed him off for Turner yesterday So I take up my quarters in Topsham, probably till next Spring. My situation here has many advantages, I have thirty dollars per month, to be sure. I have to pay my own board out of it, so that I shall clear only twenty three, but no one need tell of that! To say nothing of the advantages of Society and getting acquainted with people. it is no small benefit to be for the whole Fall and Winter so near the Libraries.  That is wherein I suffered very much last year. After being away six long months without any new books or periodicals, I must feel a little behind my fellows. It is especially important for me, if I cannot, from unfavorable circumstances, be first scholar, I ought at least to keep up the reputation of general information, literary taste, and superior writing. Now I shall have quite an advantage, as it is arranged to have all the Athenaean periodicals, reviews, magazines, reprints, etc. left in my charge.  It is no small advantage to a literary man to have the first reading of all these things. Whenever, I can, through the whole Fall term, I think, attend the morning recitation in College, Prof. Cleaveland's, the most important of all. I board only a mile from College. To be sure after it gets to be cold weather and short mornings it will be rather unschoolmasterlike to get up in the morning
Completed

and get over to College before sunrise! But then it is worth a little extra exertion.

It is very possible that I might have made more money at Turner, or by going there a while, for I had the prospect of pretty good writing school there, might perhaps have got 30 or 40 dollars in that way.

However other advantages more than counter balance that. I hardly know what my school here is to be. It is a new affair, two or three districts united, and I am to have the best scholars selected from all, any where from 40 to 50 of them.

I think I shall have a good sort of school, though the village has rather a bad reputation in that respect and there are doubtless many troublesome ones. The wages though small for a school of the character, are three or four dollars per Month higher than paid here before.
  M. L. Morse, now A.N., late Prs. Ath. Soc. Bowd. Coll. very fine man, helped me get the school, procured me his old boarding place. he taught in Topsham last winter, boarded here, and is now engaged to one of the young ladies here in the house! Of course, I run no risk of such of such a fate!
 Commencement was perhaps better than usual. It would take two or three sheets to give you an account of it. I will send you a paper with the story sometime in the week. E.L. Browne performed a part, lowest rank, but decent. Mrs. Browne, Frank & Liz Quimby were here. I only saw them a little while.  I would have
Completed

invited little Miss Quimby to Athenaean Tea party Commencement Eve, as their friends are all Peucinians and she could not go, if I had not been very much engaged, and obliged to leave early; DKE anniversary same evening. friends from abroad and high time!

By the way, when I got to my own room about 3 oclock, found a YV, Thos. Tash A.M. of Foxcroft Academy, just fairly ensconced in my bed! 
   It has been excessively hot, very dusty besides. Everyone else is all tired out clear. However believe I feel all the better for the fatigue & sleeping on the floor two or three nights for excess of company, How tough I am!
weigh 170 lbs. Far, hearty, and rugged.

The thing about Topsham, it is a great place for Society, social parties, & every thing else. "take too much time & do no good," according to Joe., for one must go, or be Joe.  I came over here yesterday P.M. First thing, an invitation to tea, somebody I never saw. I am entirely almost unacquainted here, but people seem determined it shall not be so long, I believe.

  I had a letter from Joseph the other day, just as usual, 'verry sound'   Enclosed $3,00 to me.

I received 'tother day' a letter or rather a sheet of paper regularly folded, not a word written there, and post marked Greenbush! containing a one dollar bill! What could it mean! The hand writing, be sure, looked a little like some of our folks, but not exactly, coming from Greenbush! Where is it? up Penobscot ? Money extremely convenient as I was all out at Commencement too. 
If you can decipher, or cannot, this mess of scribbled nonsense, I hope you will write immediately.
I am very anxious to hear from home,  how every thing is getting on. Charles and all his work and so forth.  Lucy I suppose has got home by this time. Joseph wrote he was going home in Sept. I think
Completed

I.S. Metcalf   Bowd.

[post mark]TOPSHAM ME SEPT 8                                                                   5

                           Milo

[right-hand side] Letters to me may be directed either to Topsham or Brunswick. I shall frequent both Post Offices. Please write much. Lucy write.

[top right hand corner, upside down] Stevens papers?

                                                                                                                                     Topsham Nov. 15th 1846

Dear Mother 

                    I received your letter about a week since; it, as usual, did me good. You may not get an answer to it yet, for a week or two. I am intending to send a parcel of letters with a package to Bangor by some one pretty soon.
 So though I do not expect to send this immediately, I thought that this Sabbath Eve, others having retired, I would scribble off a few lines before getting into bed. My Chamber feels most too cold however, to say nothing of the shadowy spectre, undefined enough, I assure you! of the morning's lesson warning me to bed that I may get up in the morning time enough to study it somewhat.

16th Well - I guess I did not write much last night, and now I find I must send my packet, if at all soon, tomorrow . So, I fear that two or three of the letters I was intending to write will fail.  also, I was intending to send unto some of you a Daguerreotype picture of my very important self. ut that also it seems will fail: I have 'set' several times but do not get any one to suit exactly. [written above this line] ? Searles  James
Completed

I believe that in your last letter you said something about a lack of suitable"food for the mind: Now I am going to send a pretty considerable 'Gob' of the very best Eating I have got hold of for a long time.

  I was at first thinking of it as a present to Sister Lucy. I hardly knew which I want to give it too most. It will do you both good. However both can have the advantage of it: I will send it for both of you.
 What is it about Joseph's going into business for himself? He has written me never a word of or about it. I should like to hear some thing about the matter.
 Please write to me whether and when Almeda goes to Mass, and where she will be there.
 Does Eliab write to you. I know nothing at all about him. I have not heard any thing from him - I do not know when - last Summer sometime, I guess. Joseph never writes a word at all about him or his affairs; in  fact hardly even about himself on his own. He write first rate letters pretty regularly, well filled with all sorts of philosophic, moralizing, Metaphysical, Mathematical, Literary, Scientifical etc. the 'Speculations' and 'practicalizations'  etc. etc. but apparently studiously refraining from all allusion to any personal circumstances, or those of any of his relatives in the flesh.  Much as I like his letters, it almost provokes me sometimes
Completed

I wish you would tell Charles as a particular Message from me that I want to go to a - a- Wedding!  It is not more than fair if he intends to be married any time this Fall or the coming Winter the he should let me know, or at least give me an 'invite' long enough beforehand so that I can make arrangements to leave here, and be there upon the "Momentous occasion".  If my school is six mos. long; they will probably want me to have a vacation sometime along.

 Come Charles, if you will only be Married at Thanksgiving, and let me know it in any decent season, I will most Sartinely favor you with my perticulary August and dignified presence and countenance, at that same time. 

Let me know quick though!

 It seems to me that Lucy is almost in danger of losing her good reputation as a letter writer.
 I am getting along finely in all respects I guess. My School is a hard bad one I had nearly 70 scholars a while. Last Week was very much relieved by the riddance of 20 of the youngest removed to another school.
It is after 11, I am getting chilly - I guess I will write no more tonight -

Please write to me - soon, - frequently - and much. Lucy Write.

                                                                                     Aff. I.S.
Completed

Topsham Dec. 6th 1846.

Dear Mother 

   It seems to be a great while since I have heard from any of you: it is more than a month I guess since I have heard at all from Milo. I have been 'threatening' to be homesick for a long time; and really came pretty near it on Thanksgiving day. I had been so expecting letters and received none. I do not know but I should have been homesick Thanksgiving day, if I had not happened to get into rather pleasant company. Thanksgiving is certainly the very bluest time of the whole year for one away from home. To be sure, both last year and this I have happened to be thrown into very pleasant society, pleasant families etc.  What sort of a Thanksgiving did you have at Milo?  When is Charles going to get married?  You know I offered to go home at Thanksgiving if he would have the wedding there. I kept right on with my school, had no vacation then, but rather expect now to have a short one along last of the month, say about Christmas.  I expect I shall have to go on to Yale College about that time, on some Society business. It will perhaps cost me some $20,00 or $30,00. I do not know exactly how much, but
Completed

perhaps it may mostly be made up to me in the Spring and I guess it will not do me any hurt in the end even if it should take a few dollars out of my own private pocket.

 I received the other day at Androscoggin Bank Topsham $90,00. being my first three monthly wages, which I drew an order for before my school was done.
  Of it $21,00 belongs to my three months board. $17,25 my summer's board. Some 25, or 30, dolls I was owing to Clothes etc. $5. for Boots & shoes. $5 for hat etc. $5,00 to the Book binder. $5,00 for Books & Stationery. Some $5,00 or 10,00 Society dues etc. in College, and I know not how much less than $100,00 though I guess on my College Bills.
 However, I do not intend to pay them all just now.
  Joseph & Eliab wrote to me that Sister Almeda and her two children had gone to Mass. to spend the Winter. When do you suppose I should have heard of it from you Milo folks? Where is Almeda going? to Royalston & Warwick? Or among the Searles? Or all round the lot? Where direct letters to her? She ought to write to me, I think.  I suppose if I went all over Mass. & Conn. by Railroad I should stand no chance of seeing her. How did little James like the idea of being left behind? I expect he is rather a good little boy, is he not?  And how is that little Jenny? you know she is a favorite of mine. Do they go to school this Winter? and
Completed

who keeps the School? I should think Charles would have considerable to do to take care of all the chores. I suppose he has to tend cattle at both barns does he not? I guess he is not likely to do much of any thing else this winter; and will need a small boy to help him at that, perhaps he has.

  How often does he have to go down to the Village?
                What in the name of all that is comely or of good report among brethren has become of my sister Lucy? It is less than an age since I have heard at all from her, or seen a word of her writing. I believe I did see a scrap of her writing in a letter from Anne sometime when she was at Bangor, last summer, was it not?
  I rather think that Joseph is likely to do pretty well in his business. You may trust him as far as any one for knowing on which side his bread is buttered.  The most I fear for him is his wearing out his mind soul in the vexations & toils of business affairs; growing old before his time.

That is of much more consequence than any thing that perishes with this short life, even bodily health - it is the health and well being of the nobler part, the intellect.

  It seems to me it must be the effect of the constant turmoil of business,perhaps to smooth & polish even by its constant rough attrition, but still to wear down the Mind perhaps to set it on edge like sour vinegar the teeth.
 If I send this sheet so, please Excuse it, and write Lucy write.     Aff. I.S.
